channel.title: NPR Topics: Science
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: What to know about Artemis II's 'wet dress rehearsal'
item.description: As astronauts prepare to fly around the moon, critical testing must occur before there is "Go" for launch.
item.content:encoded:
As astronauts prepare to fly around the moon, critical testing must occur before there is "Go" for launch.

(Image credit: Miguel J. Rodriguez Carrillo)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: A stencil of a handprint in an Indonesian cave is the oldest known rock art
item.description: Scientists have discovered what they say is the earliest known rock art, in a cave in Indonesia. They say the image dates to more than 67,000 years ago.
item.content:encoded: Scientists have discovered what they say is the earliest known rock art, in a cave in Indonesia. They say the image dates to more than 67,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Intagliata

item.title: Blue Origin pauses space tourism flights to focus on lunar lander
item.description: Blue Origin, owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, says it's stopping human spaceflights for at least two years. The move will allow it to "shift resources" to the company's lunar landing capabilities.
item.content:encoded:
Blue Origin, owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, says it's stopping human spaceflights for at least two years. The move will allow it to "shift resources" to the company's lunar landing capabilities.

(Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)
item.dc:creator: Brendan Byrne

item.title: FAQ: What is wind chill, and why is it dangerous?
item.description: Strong winds can make it feel a lot colder than the thermometer suggests. Protect yourself by covering exposed skin and sheltering inside.
item.content:encoded:
Strong winds can make it feel a lot colder than the thermometer suggests. Protect yourself by covering exposed skin and sheltering inside.

(Image credit: Matt Rourke)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Hersher

item.title: Humpback whales cast bubble nets to catch prey. They may be learning from each other
item.description: Humpback whales will sometimes use an intricate strategy to catch food called bubble-net feeding. A new study suggests they're spreading the knowledge of how to do it to each other.
item.content:encoded: Humpback whales will sometimes use an intricate strategy to catch food called bubble-net feeding. A new study suggests they're spreading the knowledge of how to do it to each other.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: Scientists shed new light on the brain's role in heart attack
item.description: Researchers discovered a feedback loop between nerve cells, the immune system and the heart. They think it shows promise as a target for future therapies.
item.content:encoded: Researchers discovered a feedback loop between nerve cells, the immune system and the heart. They think it shows promise as a target for future therapies.
item.dc:creator: Esther Landhuis

item.title: 40 years after Challenger: Lingering guilt and lessons learned
item.description: Forty years after the Challenger disaster, NPR explores the engineers' last-minute efforts to stop the launch, their decades of guilt and the vital lessons that remain critical for NASA today.
item.content:encoded:
Forty years after the Challenger disaster, NPR explores the engineers' last-minute efforts to stop the launch, their decades of guilt and the vital lessons that remain critical for NASA today.

(Image credit: Thom Baur)
item.dc:creator: Howard Berkes

item.title: What is 'frost crack' and how does it affects trees?
item.description: Sudden or severe cold temperature can cause trees to experience "frost crack." NPR's Scott Simon talks with Bill McNee of the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources about what happens and why.
item.content:encoded: Sudden or severe cold temperature can cause trees to experience "frost crack." NPR's Scott Simon talks with Bill McNee of the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources about what happens and why.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: In President's Trump's tangled science policies, experts see a unifying thread
item.description: Heading into the second year of Trump 2.0, when it comes to science, some argue Trump has no consistent ideology for decision-making. Others argue the unifying theme is destruction of science itself.
item.content:encoded: Heading into the second year of Trump 2.0, when it comes to science, some argue Trump has no consistent ideology for decision-making. Others argue the unifying theme is destruction of science itself.
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: Gladys West, mathematician whose work paved the way for GPS, dies at 95
item.description: A self-described "little farm girl" in the Jim Crow Era, Gladys West's complex and pioneering work for the U.S. Navy helped to improve billions of lives — and keep us from getting lost.
item.content:encoded: A self-described "little farm girl" in the Jim Crow Era, Gladys West's complex and pioneering work for the U.S. Navy helped to improve billions of lives — and keep us from getting lost.
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell
